title: Factoring Out Terms
text: Since all of the terms inclue $$x$$, we can factor it out of the equation: $$x \left(x^2+11x+10\right)=0$$,

title: Grouping
text: Now we can factor by grouping. $$1\times10=10$$, so we should look for two numbers that multiply to $$10$$ and add to $$11$$. $$10$$ and $$1$$ satisfy this.

title: Grouping
pacedSpeech: What is the factored expression?

title: Grouping
text: We can rewrite the expression as $$x^2+x+10x+10$$ or $$x^2+x+10x+10$$. Let's factor $$x^2+x$$. $$x$$ goes into both expressions, so let's rewrite this as $$x \left(x+1\right)$$. Now, factor $$10x+10$$. $$10$$ goes into both terms, so it is rewritten as $$10\left(x+1\right)$$. Because both $$x \left(x+1\right)$$ and $$10\left(x+1\right)$$ are multiplied by $$x+1$$, we can use the distributive property to rewrite the expression as $$\left(x+1\right) \left(x+10\right)$$.

Let's factor  x squared, plus x .  x  goes into both expressions, so let's rewrite this as , x, parentheses x plus 1,  . Now, factor  10 x plus 10 .  10  goes into both terms, so it is rewritten as , 10 times, parentheses x plus 1,  . Because both , x, parentheses x plus 1,   and , 10 times, parentheses x plus 1,   are multiplied by  x plus 1 , we can use the distributive property to rewrite the expression as  parentheses x plus 1,  times, parentheses x plus 10,  .

title: Zero Product Property
text: Now, we can bring back the $$x$$, making our equation $$x \left(x+1\right) \left(x+10\right)$$. Using the Zero Product Property, we can set all the terms equal to zero and solve for $$x$$.
